This experiment is for those who want to try different methods, and see wha=
t works.
I thought you'd agree with that, since you say so on the home page=
 here.

There is of course more than one possible outcome: 1 or more people=
 can get the right result, and 1 or more people get an incorrect result.=C2=
=A0 The goal would be to continue experiments, and allow those people to co=
ntinue to try different methods, and different opinions on what works and w=
hat doesn't=C2=A0 (like yours), and see what works.

If you're not really i=
nteresting in trying different methods and seeing what works, feel free to =
ignore our efforts.

Rj



--- On Sun, 7/11/10, Frank Sumption <purplealien=
girl@...> wrote:

From: Frank Sumption <purplealiengirl@...>
Su=
bject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Improved protocol
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Su=
nday, July 11, 2010, 2:04 PM







=C2=A0



  


    
      
      
     =
 =C2=A0Whatever you do, do not do your own EVP recordings! There is only on=
e possible outcome of the test, and that's "see, we told everyone, nothing =
to it". I think the otherside is not interested in performing for skeptics =
that would not accept it anyway. 

=C2=A0
=C2=A0and don't even ask, I don't=
 play those games either. There is far more than enough to prove to any thi=
nking person this stuff is real. 
=C2=A0
=C2=A0F-S


On Sun, Jul 11, 2010 a=
t 9:08 AM, John S <phenom_investigator @...> wrote:


=C2=A0 






S=
ince we're talking about experiments and protocols here are some ideas to i=
mprove
the protocol RJ suggested initially. Using a test target is one way =
of establishing a 
truth in time, which is the basis of this experiment. Bu=
t there are a couple of issues.
=C2=A0
It is quite possible that someone co=
uld discern the target through remote viewing alone.
This would negate the =
need for involvement of a spirit communicator or discarnate entity.
Outcome=
s=C2=A0depend on the word of those reporting. The true skeptic (not cynic) =
would 
therefore say that this experiment contains a basic flaw in that it=
=C2=A0does not uniquely 
indicate that the information was obtained in the =
prescribed manner. Providing access
to the raw audio file would not necessa=
rily constitute proof either, since many of these 
communications can only =
be heard by certain people, 
=C2=A0
If the audio file were quite clear, tim=
ing=C2=A0=C2=A0becomes an issue. In other words, when was 
the audio actual=
ly recorded?=C2=A0 This issue can be mitigated simply by requiring any
clai=
mant to email the audio file to a trusted party before the test ends. It wo=
uld be best 
if the trusted party were not otherwise invovled in the experi=
ment and it was=C2=A0 their duty 
simply to=C2=A0collect the claims. Once a=
ll claims had been collected they could be posted 
publicly for review=C2=
=A0by the community in general.=C2=A0 The experimenter could decide if any =

of the claims seemed to have hit,=C2=A0and this decision could be reviewed=
 by anyone if desired. 
=C2=A0
The important detail however is that this ex=
periment does not completely answer the 
question. It is a first attempt an=
d certainly can be improved on successive trials.
=C2=A0
Successive trials =
are always a good idea, since it provides replication. And it would be
best=
 if others replicated the experiment using a very similar protocol. If thes=
e were to
succeed, the community could then state that out of X trials Y ha=
d succeeded (by 
some definition of success) potentially=C2=A0giving a succ=
ess rate above that expected 
by random chance. This would make the outcome=
 quantifiable and measureable 
and thus meaningful.
=C2=A0
But also importa=
nt to note, this would only prove the potential veracity of the messages.
I=
t would not (and cannot as far as I can tell) prove the origin of the messa=
ges. This detail
will, I fear, remain a matter for belief and speculation f=
or quite some time to come.
=C2=A0
=C2=A0
=C2=A0
